Judul: THE IMPACT OF BUILDING HEIGHT ON URBAN HEAT ISLAND PHENOMENON IN AN URBANIZED AREA
Abstrak:
Over the last decade, “livability” has become an increasingly popular term used in
urban policy due to higher concern in to make a city as a desireable place to live.
Nonetheless, the rampant urbanisation has led to the changes of the land use into
the built-up area. A study has shown that the land cover trend in Jakarta has been
dominated by built-up area. This large-scale changes have led to urban climate
change and caused an increased annual mean air temperature in a city can be 1-3 ?
warmer than the rural surroundings which known as urban heat island (UHI) that
may cause degradation environment quality.
A study in urban microclimate is gaining importance regarding the occurrence of
UHI since it is expected to help improving the performance of the adjacent
buildings with air temperature, wind flow and other climatic indicators. In the
previous studies, researchers have discovered that height of the buildings affects
the surrounding microclimate in which the temperature lapse rate can be significant
in high-rise buildings. In contrast, increasing building height is presumably useful
in providing shading to the environment.
To probe the influence of building height in the urban heating, a micro-scale urban
model has been employed to study the influence of building height on the
surrounding UHI effect. Sudirman Central Business District (SCBD) in Jakarta,
Indonesia was chosen as a case study due to its characteristics which its area
occupied by mostly high-rise and skyscraper buildings. Four different simulations
through numerical models in Computational Fluid Dynamics (CFD) have been
made in two different season, dry and wet season. The first case was calculated
without considering heat transfer, whilst the second case was calculated heat from
vehicles in the road and building. Furthermore, in the second case, height of
buildings was simulated 150% higher and 50% lower than the present condition.
The analysis on the simulations will be examined regarding their characteristics
based on the urban configuration.iv
It is found that two of parameters on urban microclimate which are magnitude of
velocity and temperature distribution were generally affected by the wind inflow
direction and buildings configuration. Combination of the existence of tall buildings
and narrow streets entrapped heat and reduce the air flow, resulting in high
temperatures as well. Considering anthropogenic heat source in the simulations was
also giving significant impact on the analysis. Moreover, heat from vehicles was
deemed as the biggest contributor than heat release from buildings at rooftops since
it is too high to influence air temperature at pedestrian level.
The study was only performed for an isolated building geometry and did not
investigate the influence of building materials, building cooling loads generated by
human activity and the existence of urban greenery. Thus, it is necessary to consider
those aspects to attain deeper understanding on the UHI occurrence in the future
works. Eventually, this study attempts to giving an understanding on how
microclimate analysis can be performed at the early stages of the planning process,
when urban planners could be well informed of the environmental impact to
consider the town planning as proposed strategies to mitigate UHI
